publicationStmt.publisher: The Characters that shaped the Silk Road - A Database and Digital Paleography of Tarim

seg.seg: ... you breathe in ...
... they bind your acting. Thereupon he says: «...
... he drank blood; flesh from the body at another time ...
... you have hidden the confused man. He pointed out to you: «The hunters killed ...
... life in ... try to take away ...
... they ate. Flesh of the thigh he gave to his wife as food; another ...
lawlessly he cut off your hands, feet, nose and ears; [your] body ...
... you ... 2. || Janahitaiṣin says: «Having considered this, being clung ...
... I wish ... || Janahitaiṣin says: «Isn't it ...
... many without number ...
like the Vipula mountain the hearts of all beings ... food for me ...
... me the dear one, who [am] not in a tree cavity. They brought me out of love for [my] son. Who does not ...
whom I gave clothes without deceit. 3. Without beginning ...
... own beloved; these names ...
I have compared all the signs of love. 3. From the birth ...
... I have skinned my own dear ones. Unsweet I had them killed ...
Ich häutete meine lieben [und] ließ sie noch unsanft töten.
I skinned my beloved ones [and] also had them killed ungently.
... shame. 4. But even this compassionate mother of mine ...
... if not ...

p.note: According to 249 "[w]ritten in medium ductus, it is quite clearly preserved, except for a large gap in the middle of line five. It is from the middle of a large nine line manuscript."
(vi)pul-ṣlempa: cf. a1 vipul ṣuläṣ lyutār tpär.

list.item: According to [[Broomhead I]]: 249 "[w]ritten in medium ductus, it is quite clearly preserved, except for a large gap in the middle of line five. It is from the middle of a large nine line manuscript."

Translations from [[Schmidt KT 1974]]
Lines Translation Pages
b7 Ich häutete meine lieben [und] ließ sie noch unsanft töten. 460


[[Broomhead I]]: 250-251 translates:

a1 You breateh in [and] therefore ...

a2 They bind you to do. Thereupon he speaks: ...

a3 Therefore grain, blood and flesh from the body at another time

a4 You have hidden the male sign. This one pointed at you. 'Kill the hunter!' (he said).

a5 Life in ...: Make an effort to seize it!

a6 They devoured ...: You gave your wife the flesh of the hip to eat.

a7 The hand, the feet, the nose [and] the ears you cut up finely. [And] th ebody ...

a8 [He breathes]: Janahitaiṣi speaks 'Having considered (this) and having become attached ...'

a9 I love ...: Janahitaiṣi speaks:

b1 He asked. Many and without number [are] ...

b2 Like a mountain without a root my heart is to be eaten by all the beings.

b3 me the dear one, who [am] not in the tree-cavity. [He] brought me to the son through (his) love.

b4 Whom I gave clothes without deceit. 3. Not previously ...

b5 ... [my] own beloved. These ... name ...

b6 [With] love I compared all [the] signs. 3. From the birth

b7 I have torn away my loved one: [And] unloved I caused them to be killed.

b8 shame. 4. But the compassionate mother [and] even my ...

b9 If there is indeed nobody at all left [then] ...

b1 m(ā)k(a) •: I changed • to – because there is no punctuation expected at this position. b4 3: obviously an error by the copyist, who wrote ‹3› instead of ‹: 2› –Martin (Mon, 2020-03-09, 19:32)

a1 ... you breathe in ... a2 ... they bind your acting. Thereupon he says: «... a3 ... he drank blood; flesh from the body at another time ... a4 ... you have hidden the confused man. He pointed out to you: «The hunters killed ... a5 ... life in ... try to take away ... a6 ... they ate. Flesh of the thigh he gave to his wife as food; another ... a7 lawlessly he cut off your hands, feet, nose and ears; [your] body ... a8 ... you ... 2. || Janahitaiṣin says: «Having considered this, being clung ... a9 ... I wish ... || Janahitaiṣin says: «Isn't it ... b1 ... many without number ... b2 like the Vipula mountain the hearts of all beings ... food for me ... b3 ... me the dear one, who [am] not in a tree cavity. They brought me out of love for [my] son. Who does not ... b4 whom I gave clothes without deceit. 3. Without beginning ... b5 ... own beloved; these names ... b6 I have compared all the signs of love. 3. From the birth ... b7 ... I have skinned my own dear ones. Unsweet I had them killed ... b8 ... shame. 4. But even this compassionate mother of mine ... b9 ... if not ...

div.p: <citedRange>250-251</citedRange></bibl> translates: </p><p>a1 You breateh in [and] therefore ... </p><p>a2 They bind you to do. Thereupon he speaks: ... </p><p>a3 Therefore grain, blood and flesh from the body at another time </p><p>a4 You have hidden the male sign. This one pointed at you. 'Kill the hunter!' (he said). </p><p>a5 Life in ...: Make an effort to seize it! </p><p>a6 They devoured ...: You gave your wife the flesh of the hip to eat. </p><p>a7 The hand, the feet, the nose [and] the ears you cut up finely. [And] th ebody ... </p><p>a8 [He breathes]: Janahitaiṣi speaks 'Having considered (this) and having become attached ...' </p><p>a9 I love ...: Janahitaiṣi speaks: </p><p>b1 He asked. Many and without number [are] ... </p><p>b2 Like a mountain without a root my heart is to be eaten by all the beings. </p><p>b3 me the dear one, who [am] not in the tree-cavity. [He] brought me to the son through (his) love. </p><p>b4 Whom I gave clothes without deceit. 3. Not previously ... </p><p>b5 ... [my] own beloved. These ... name ... </p><p>b6 [With] love I compared all [the] signs. 3. From the birth </p><p>b7 I have torn away my loved one: [And] unloved I caused them to be killed. </p><p>b8 shame. 4. But the compassionate mother [and] even my ... </p><p>b9 If there is indeed nobody at all left [then] ... </p><p><ref type="ms" target="__b1"/><hi>m(ā)k(a) •</hi>: I changed • to – because there is no punctuation expected at this position. <ref type="ms" target="__b4"/> <hi>3</hi>: obviously an error by the copyist, who wrote ‹3› instead of ‹: 2› –Martin (Mon, 2020-03-09, 19:32)</p></project_comment>
